facts.text: Upto August 15, 1947, Gwalior was an Indian State and its Courts were foreign courts within s. 2(5) of the Indian Code of Civil Procedure.
By Instrument of Accession entered into by August 15, 1947, between Ruler of Gwalior and Dominion of India, certain subjects transferred but Civil Procedure not one of them.
In April 1948, Rulers of Gwalior, Indore and others formed United State of Madhya Bharat.
Fresh Instrument of Accession executed on July 19, 1948, by United State to Dominion of India; became Part B State under Constitution.
Appellant instituted suit on May 15, 1947, in Court of District Judge, Gwalior, for recovery of Rs. 6,92,236.15-0 against respondents, sons and legal representatives of late Munshi Ishwar Saran.
Writs of summons served on respondents on September 12, 1947; respondents did not appear.
On November 18, 1947, trial Judge ordered suit to proceed ex parte.
Decree passed on November 18, 1948, with costs and interest by Additional District Judge, Gwalior.
On August 9, 1949, appellant applied for transfer of decree to Court of Civil Judge, Allahabad, where properties of respondents' father situate.
On April 25, 1950, Gwalior Court ordered transfer of execution case and issuance of certificate to Civil Judge, 1st Class, Allahabad.
On September 14, 1951, Gwalior Court made order sending decree for execution to Civil Judge, 1st Grade, Allahabad, with certificate under Order XXI, Rule 6.
On October 16, 1951, appellant filed execution application in Civil Judge, Allahabad, for Rs. 8,98,777-0 (Execution Case No.47 of 1951).
Respondents filed objections under s. 47 CPC on February 8, 1952: Gwalior Court foreign, no submission to jurisdiction, decree nullity, not executable.
Execution case transferred to Allahabad High Court under s. 34 CPC as Extraordinary Miscellaneous Case No. 1 of 1954.
Brij Mohan Lal J. held decree by foreign court, not binding, execution dismissed.
Appeal to Division Bench upheld single judge, applying Sirdar Gurdial Singh v. Maharaja of Faridkot; Gwalior foreign till Jan 26, 1950.
Appeal to Supreme Court on certificate under Art. 133(1)(a) and (c).

legal_issues.text: Was the decree passed by the Gwalior Court on November 18, 1948, a decree of a foreign court?
Could the Gwalior Court order transfer of the decree for execution to Allahabad Civil Court?
If not, was the decree executable at Allahabad under ss. 43, 44 CPC?
Could respondents object to execution on ground decree absolute nullity as foreign court decree?

petitioner_arguments.text: Gwalior Court ceased to be foreign due to constitutional documents; United State of Madhya Bharat part of Dominion of India.
Post-Constitution, Madhya Bharat Part B State; decree took Indian nationality, executable.
Decree valid in Madhya Bharat; only impediment to execution removed by integration.
Subsequent changes in CPC (Adaptation Orders 1950, Act II of 1951) made Gwalior Court competent to transfer decree under ss. 38-39 CPC.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: CPC ss. 38-42, Adaptation of Laws Order 1950, CPC Amendment Act II of 1951 s.20

petitioner_arguments.text: Executable under ss. 43-44 CPC as decree of Part B State court.

respondent_arguments.text: Gwalior Court foreign; no submission to jurisdiction; decree absolute nullity.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: CPC s.13, s.2(5); Sirdar Gurdial Singh v. Maharaja of Faridkot

respondent_arguments.text: Constitutional changes, accessions did not affect status; Gwalior foreign till Jan 26, 1950.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Indian Independence Act 1947, Instruments of Accession

respondent_arguments.text: No provision makes pre-Constitution decree executable; Art. 261(3) not retroactive.
Transfer orders invalid as Gwalior Court not governed by Indian CPC at relevant times.

court_reasoning.text: At time of decree (Nov 18, 1948), Gwalior Court foreign per s.2(5) CPC (post-1948 Adaptation); respondents no submission to jurisdiction; decree nullity outside Madhya Bharat.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Actor sequitur forum rei; extra territorium jus dicenti impune non paretur.

court_reasoning.text: Constitutional documents (Accessions, Covenant) did not integrate fully; Madhya Bharat retained sovereignty till Constitution; no retrospective effect.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cited Rao Shiv Bahadur Singh, Virendra Singh; Constitution prospective.

court_reasoning.text: Gwalior Court on Sept 14, 1951 (transfer order) different from court that passed decree (under different CPC); no power under s.39 CPC to transfer.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Decrees in ss.37-42 are those passed under Indian CPC.

court_reasoning.text: Ss.43,44 CPC not applicable: decree not by Part B State court at time passed (pre-Constitution); no notification under old s.44.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Amendments prospective; no naturalisation of foreign decree.

court_reasoning.text: Respondents can resist as nullity; vested right not affected by changes.
court_reasoning.key_observation: S.13 CPC substantive; Kishori Lal v. Shanti Devi principle applies.

holdings.text: Decree of Gwalior Court on Nov 18, 1948, was of foreign court; nullity outside Madhya Bharat; remained so post-changes.
Gwalior Court had no power under ss.38-39 CPC to transfer decree to Allahabad Court.
Ss.43-44 CPC inapplicable to this decree.
Judgment-debtors entitled to object on nullity ground.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sirdar Gurdial Singh v. Maharaja of Faridkot
precedents_cited.relevance: Decree by foreign court without jurisdiction or submission is nullity.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rao Shiv Bahadur Singh v. State of Vindhya Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Accession and Covenant integrated states by accession only, no full merger.

precedents_cited.case_name: Virendra Singh v. State of Uttar Pradesh

precedents_cited.relevance: Pre-partition order retains character unless specific change; analogous to no change in nullity.

precedents_cited.case_name: Janardhan Reddy v. State of Hyderabad

precedents_cited.relevance: Crucial date for validity is date of decree.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Defined foreign court, judgment; execution, transfer provisions; inapplicable or not retrospective to decree.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Full faith and credit; prospective; adaptation of laws.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure Amendment Act, 1951 (Act II of 1951)
statutes_cited.relevance: Extended CPC to Part B States; savings for prior rights/decrees.

statutes_cited.name: Madhya Bharat Indian Civil Procedure Adaptation Act (Act 70 of Samvat 2006/1949)
statutes_cited.relevance: Adapted Indian CPC in Madhya Bharat from Jan 23, 1950; savings for prior decrees.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; decree not executable in Allahabad as nullity of foreign court; no valid transfer or applicability of ss.43-44 CPC.

key_quotes.text: "Under these circumstances there was, in their Lordships opinion, nothing to take this case out of the general rule, that the plaintiff must sue in the court to which the Defendant is subject at the time of suit (Actor sequitur forum rei)"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Sirdar Gurdial Singh; core principle for foreign jurisdiction.

key_quotes.text: "A decree pronounced in absentem by a foreign Court, to the jurisdiction of which the Defendant has not in any way submitted himself, is by international law an absolute nullity."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The Constitution is prospective and not retrospective."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: No retroactive validation of foreign decree.
